titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Employed most of the morning, and again after dinner in search of George, whom I find it impossible to keep at home— I was in State-Street to see Mr: Quincy, but he was not in town— Read lé Batteux, Sur la Construction Oratoire; but wrote nothing this day— Walk in the Evening, with Mrs: A— My brother was here this morning, and called again as he returned to Quincy at Night.

2. Went with Mr: Buchanan this morning to Trinity Church, and heard Dr: Gardiner preach a Sermon upon the atonement— It was Communion day— In the afternoon I heard Mr: Emerson— Read Tillotson’s Sermons 123. 124. Mr: W. Smith was here at tea— Mr: & Mrs: B. pass’d the Evening at Dr: Welsh’s.

3. Mr: and Mrs: Buchanan went to Salem this Morning in the Stage and returned in the Evening. Charlotte Welsh went with them— Mr: Gallison this morning called upon me to enquire again respecting his entrance in my Office— I told him the disadvantages to which he must expect to be subject, if he should come into it, and left him to decide for himself— I called at Mr: Hall’s Office, where I found Mr: T. Pinckney. Also at J. Allen’s Office. Saw Mr: Quincy, at the Suffolk Insurance Office— Evening walk in the Mall— Found Mr: DeGrand at my house on returning home— He supp’d with us.

4. Rain, the greatest part of the day; which confined me at home, and I employed it altogether in writing— Walking in the Mall this Evening we met Mr: Shaw and Mr: B. Welles.— Resumed the reading of French, with George.

5. Called at Mrs: Carter’s to see Mr: Pinckney, but he was at Salem— I once more opened my Office, in my own house, in Court-Street— Saw Mr: Quincy, in State-Street, and settled business with him— Saw there also the President’s proclamation calling Congress together, to meet 26th: of October— My brother, and Charlotte Welsh dined with us.— Club, this Evening at Dr: Eliot’s—which was not very fully attended— I afterwards pass’d half an hour at Mr: S. Dexter’s, where were Mr: & Mrs: Buchanan— Mr: S. A. Otis and his family, and Judge Parker, and his wife— Wrote less than I ought.

6. Mr: and Mrs: Buchanan left us this morning at 9. In the Stage to Providence— His residence is in the neighbourhood of Baltimore—to which they are now going— His kinsman, Mr: Rogers breakfasted with us; and Dr: Welsh was here. I employed the forenoon in writing— Dined at Mr: William Phillips’s, with a company of twenty Gentlemen— It was a dinner to Mr: T. Pinckney— I spent some time this afternoon at my Office— Walk’d with Mrs: Adams and George in the Evening.

div.p: 7. The Senior Class having left the College, I have suspended the delivery of my lectures untill after Commencement. But I went to Cambridge, at Noon, to attend the Declamation at 2. I dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s— The Declamation was indifferent— I went and returned in the Stage, owing to the warmth of the weather— On returning home I spent two or three hours, untill dark at my Office, and at the Athenaeum.— Walk’d in the Evening with Mrs: Adams and George.—

8. The rain, with my occupations confined me this whole day to the house— I employed part of it in writing, and part in packing and unpacking books. To a person whose life is so much that of a wanderer, as mine has been, there is nothing so troublesome as a large Library— During the period of my life when I possess’d the means of collecting Books I used them to such an extent that since my return to this Country, I have never had, and can scarcely flatter myself with the hope of ever having a place for receiving them with such an arrangement as may give me the free use of them— I have them now in extreme confusion, and know not when I shall get them into better order— Young Mr: Sanger called this afternoon, and I return’d him his Oration for the Exhibition, revised. Mrs: Adams was unwell— In the Evening I read part of the first Book of Phillips’s Poem on Cider— In which the most remarkable passages are the destruction of Ariconium, and the walking Mountain.

9. Heard Mr: Emerson the whole day— Walked in the Evening with Mrs: Adams and George. Wrote a little, and read Tillotson’s Sermons 125 and 126. The weather was excessively warm, after a rainy night & cold morning.

10. After spending the day, in very close application to the subject of my lectures, I went this afternoon with George, and bathed at the Alms-House-wharf— After returning home, and as he was undressing for bed, we discovered that he had received a severe hurt— While I was at Cambridge last Friday, he went over to my neighbour Mr: Foster’s where he was playing with two of his Grand-children, John Apthorp and William Otis; and was thrown from a Swing with such violence that he received a violent bruise upon his hip, and as we have hitherto supposed also upon his right shoulder—but as he complained little of it, and has been cheerful as usual, we apprehended nothing more than a bruise. It seems however instead of healing like the contusion on his hip; to be more irritable and painful now than it has been hitherto.

11. Dr: Welsh examined George’s arm and shoulder this morning, but thought no bone was displaced or broken. I spent the day engaged in reading, and in writing for my lecture— Mr: Pierce called on me from Cambridge to look over his latin Oration for exhibition, which I did. Mr: Munroe, the printer of the partners Oliver and Munroe, came to me to write him proposals for publishing an Edition of Johnson’s large Dictionary; and requested me to superintend the publication; the last of which I declined— Walked in the Evening with Mrs: A— I called upon Mr: Shaw, and borrowed the first volume of his Johnson—

12. My father and mother came in from Quincy this morning with Louisa Smith. I went with my father to Cambridge, and attended a meeting of the Academy— Thinly attended— I dined afterwards at Dr: Holmes’s— With Judge Davis, Mr: Emerson, Mr: Hedge, Mr: Farrar, Mr: Willard, and Mr: Carey.— My father dined at President Webber’s— I returned with him to Boston, and they soon afterwards went out to Quincy— By their advice I took George to Mr: Hewes, the bone-setter— He told me that George’s arm was dislocated, and his Collar-bone broken. He replaced the arm however immediately in the socket, and with little pain to the child—and put a plaister on the clavicle, which he assured me would in a few days be healed.— I attended the Club at Judge Mr Emerson’s. Mr: Kendall the Englishman, and Mr: Dufief the author of the Grammar were there— I had some conversation with both of them.

13. John Smith and Mrs: T. B. Adams came into town this morning— Young Mr: Gallison came, and desired to be considered as a Student with me from this day— He is going to Marblehead for a fortnight, and I recommended to him the books he is to read in his absence— I called at Mrs: Newton’s, and she referr’d me to Mr: S. Higginson junr: whom I afterwards saw, at the insurance Office— The afternoon and Evening I spent at home; confined by a heavy rain. S. Abbot a Scholar from Cambridge came with his part, and two others for examination, which employed me part of the Evening— I also wrote the proposals for Oliver and Munroe, but nothing more.

14. This day was the visitation of the public Schools by the Select-Men, which I attended with them untill 12. O’Clock, when I was obliged to go to Cambridge— I attended the South-Schools of Mr: Bullard and Mr: Webb, and the School in Hawkins Street of Mr: Perkins— Here the two parties which had divided to visit the North & South Schools, joined together. Here we met the Governor and some other Gentlemen— Among the rest Mr: Ph: N. Nicholas of Virginia. As I was going up to Cambridge I met Dr: Welsh who was coming to my house— I walk’d to Cambridge— Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s, and attended the Declamation at 2. O’Clock— The last before Commencement— After the Declamation I heard all the declaimers, for the Exhibition next week speak their parts, which employed me untill between 5 and 6. O’Clock. I walk’d home; and as usual found myself too much fatigued for serious occupation in the Evening— I read however to Mrs: Adams several of Bacon’s Essays.

15. Mr: Francis Parkman called upon me twice. In Examining his performance for Commencement and hearing him, and revising the other pieces submitted to me, I again employed the greatest part of the day, and wrote nothing upon my lecture. Saw Mr: Higginson again at the Insurance Office, and settled with him— Evening walk in the Mall; and read a few more of Bacon’s Essays.

16. Heard Dr: Osgood of Medford, at Mr: Emerson’s, the whole day: George with me in the afternoon— Walk’d with Mrs: Adams in the Mall in the Evening— Read Tillotson’s Sermons 127. 128. and some Essays of Bacon— Dr: Osgood is a preacher superior to the common herd— There is an affecting solemnity in his delivery, the effect of which is almost ruined by the aukwardness of his manners, and the vulgarity of his pronunciation— His composition has the same merit, and in a lighter degree the same faults— His morning Sermon was from Matthew XII.7.— Mercy & not Sacrifice; and drew an ingenious comparison between these two Common-Place topics, as Evidences of Religion— The Afternoon Discourse, was from Acts XXIV.25.— The division excellent— 1. The mode of Paul’s preaching— Reasoning. 2. The subjects of his preaching— Righteousness— Temperance, and Judgment to come— 3. The Effect of his preaching— Felix trembled— Sterne has a good Sermon on this Story; but the Dr: did not appear to have borrowed any thing from him. The Sermons I read of Tillotson this day are on the parable of the rich man and Lazarus— There is in one of them a curious account of the different kinds of Revelation, according to the opinions of the antient Jews.— I wrote some letters of Introduction for Mr: T. K. Jones’s son—to Mr: Gentz— Mr: Cohen— & Mr: Schickler at Berlin.

17. During the whole of the day excepting when I was obliged, at noon to go into the town, I was occupied in writing for my lecture, and reading various books— I spent about an hour at the Athenaeum reading the recent British periodical publications— Mrs: Welsh called at my house early this Evening, after which I walk’d in the Mall with Mrs: Adams.

18. By the Blessing of God, I have this day a third son, born at half-past eight O’Clock this Morning— Just before 2. My wife waked me, and desired me to procure the Doctor and Nurse, immediately. I went myself for Dr: Welsh, and sent James for Mrs: Alker— I returned in about half-an-hour with the Dr: and found the nurse already here— Mrs: Adams was still so well that the Dr: and myself went soon after to bed; and rose again about seven O’Clock; the pains had become sharp, but not yet frequent— By the time we had breakfasted they were violent, and came in quick succession— The process was not of the most usual and favorable kind, though not the most dangerous. The sufferings of the mother for about an hour were extreme— In the birth the infant appeared to have suffered some injury, and had when first-born no appearance of life— In about five minutes however, while preparation was making to set its lungs in motion, it commenced respiration of itself, and very soon appeared to be in full life— It is a very large child, and to appearance weighs as much as George and John together, at their birth— About half an hour afterwards my Sister Smith and her son John arrived here— I was going with John to the exhibition at Cambridge, but now could not leave my wife— John Smith went alone— I wrote immediately to Mrs: Johnson, and carried the letter myself at noon to the Post-Office— John Smith returned after dinner from Cambridge, and went out alone to Quincy, leaving his mother here— I requested her to stay this Night with us, to which she readily consented— Mr: Boylston called on us this morning— Mr: Keith also from Alexandria visited me to enquire concerning Mrs: Hall’s business—with the state of which I acquainted him. In the Evening there was a fire at the North part of the Town, which kept me up late; and which broke out again in the Night— But I did not hear the bells the second time— There were five old wooden houses burnt down. We were not without concern at Night on account of the Child.— Met Mr: Emerson in the Mall.

19. My brother and his wife came into Town from Quincy, this morning; they called here for a few minutes; but did not stay to dine— I was uneasy, and alarmed on the Child’s account untill late this afternoon when he was relieved, and we consider him as out of all unusual danger— I therefore attended the club at Mr: Edward Gray’s— It was moderately attended, but not very full— I finished the first sketch of my Lecture 26— But the occurrences in my family have in a great measure disqualified me for present Study— I have not enough of the Stoic in my Soul.

20. My wife and child have both been this day, better than I could or did expect; the day has been dull and gloomy with a cold North-East wind and rain— They confined me to the house excepting at the middle of the day when I carried a second Letter for Mrs: Johnson to the Post-Office— Of which my wife herself wrote a few lines.— Yet though past at home, the day was an idle one in respect to my studies— It seems that nothing but the pressure of immediate necessity can drive me to them.— I began Sketch of Lecture 27. but did not write five lines— William Smith called upon me this afternoon, with his Oration for Commencement, to be examined.

21. I wrote a line to President Webber respecting the admission of John Smith to a degree ad eundem, on Commencement day; but found no opportunity for sending it— We had such incessant rain through the day, that I was confined to the house, untill the Evening— I then went to the Athenaeum, and call’d at Shaw’s Office, but found he was confined at home by indisposition— I wrote part of my Lecture; though not so much as I ought.

22. Rain continued all last Night, and the greatest part of this day.— At Noon I walk’d into town, and call’d at Mr: Shaw’s Office, but he was not yet out. In the afternoon John Smith came in from Quincy for his mother, and she went out with him— Her company has been a great relief and assistance to my wife, who regretted much her departure— Young Fish who graduates next week brought me his own part, and that of Merrill for examination— I sent by him, my letter to President Webber.— Walking this Evening in the Mall I met Mr: De Grand, with whom I went to his lodgings— And he shewed me the Description, and a model of Montgolfier’s new invention of the Belier Hydraulique— Mrs: Adams has been this day more unwell than any former day since her confinement— I wrote something for my lectures.

23. Heard Mr: Emerson both parts of the day, and I took George with me— Read Tillotson’s Sermons 129 and 130. Mrs: Welsh was here this afternoon— The Doctor has had the prevalent influenza, which has prevented him from calling here. Wrote a little of my Lecture, and walk’d this Evening in the Mall.

24. I met on the exchange this day my old friend James Bridge, and invited him to come home and dine with me, but he was engaged— He promised however that he would come to-morrow. I employed the greatest part of the day in reading and in writing for my lecture—

25. Mr: Bridge dined with me, and I had much Conversation with him upon the course of our adventures since we left College. Mr: Munroe called on me this afternoon, and brought a copy of his proposals for the publication of Johnson’s Dictionary. I neither wrote nor read much this day— But I pass’d a great part of the morning at my office.

26. Mr: Boylston called on me his morning, and took me to Cambridge. Mr: Gray of Roxbury was also with him in the Carriage— I called at Dr: Waterhouse’s, and went immediately thence to the philosophy Chamber and Library. The Procession very soon went to the Meeting House, and the Commencement performances were delivered— They were rendered rather more tedious than usual, by Mr: Stickney’s Oration, of an hour and a quarter, on the proof which Prophecy furnishes to Christianity— The valedictory Latin Oration by Mr: Aspinwall was equally remarkable for its brevity. The other performances were hardly equal to the average of these Occasions— Haven’s Poem was omitted, he being very sick, and unable to attend— In conferring the degrees the President’s Memory failed him, and he was for a minute or two at fault for words— He recovered himself however so as to get through. I dined in the Hall, where I met of my old Classmates—Fiske— Hunnewell, Laurence and Prentiss— After dinner I visited William Smith at his chamber; took coffee at Dr: Waterhouse’s where I met Mr: and Mrs: Boies and their family; and returned with Mr: Boylston to Boston about Sun-set— Mr: Shaw was here in the Evening— George very unwell with the tooth-ache, untill late at Night.

27. I have been not very well for some days, and this Evening was more so than before. I walk’d, notwithstanding in the Mall, where I met Mr: Tyng, and had some conversation with him— At home I have written and read something— My observations upon’s Bacon’s Essays, and Johnson’s Rasselas which I have lately been reading, I expect to lose, for want of Time to put them into writing.

28. I supposed there was to be this day a Meeting of the Historical Society, and went at 4. this afternoon to their Hall. But it was the day before Commencement, and I miss’d it by my inattention— Spent the afternoon at the Athenaeum, reading pamphlets and periodical works. In the Evening I attended the annual meeting of the
Directors of the Fire and Marine Insurance Company, where they chose me one of the Directors for the year ensuing.— The meeting was very thinly attended— I find myself still somewhat indisposed.

29. On rising this morning I found myself with a cold, and some oppression upon the lungs, which increased through the day. My Mother came in from Quincy, with Louisa Smith, and my John— I went out with them in the Evening, but was very unwell— My father dined at Mr: Lyman’s in Waltham, and did not reach home untill late in the Evening.

30. I had a very restless, and entirely sleepless Night, and was all this day feeble and feverish, with other symptoms of illness— The disease is very prevalent, and bears the name of Influenza— I did not go out in the forenoon; but after dinner heard Mr: Thacher of Dedham— Mr: Black and Mr: Beale, with their Ladies, and my uncle Adams were at my father’s this Evening.— Read my father’s letters to Mrs: Warren.

31. I had some sleep in the Night, but very little; the Stricture upon my lungs and the fever continues with some small increase— I returned to Boston however with George this morning; and John Smith with his Sister Caroline, and Hannah Smith went out in the afternoon— On reaching home I found Mrs: Adams had been extremely ill since Saturday Night, and she continued so through the whole day— I received a letter from Mr: A. H. Everett engaging an entrance into my Office, as a Student at Law— After reaching home, I did not go out again for the day, which was one of the hottest of the Season untill towards Evening, when by a change of the wind, it became very cool.

Day. Differs in nothing from the last Month, excepting that since the Vacation Commenced at Cambridge, I do not attend there on Fridays, and since the birth of my child my course has necessarily become again irregular.
